history.content:
I personally think that's a pretty heavy workload, and it'd require very good time management, but also doable. Others can feel free to chime in.

-----

Not a huge issue, but note 70 and 61C both come with heavy workload. If you plan to do so, be ready to have less free time (and potentially bad grades).

-----

Maybe if CS70 and CS61C were your only technicals, it would work. I have heard that EE16A is a time drain, so I would just take those first two and spend as much time on those.

--- 

I'm in 61C and 70 right now and while there are plenty of us doing it it's pretty hard time wise for me.

---

I took CS61C, CS70, EE16B, and a history breath. It's a pretty big time crunch, even though I P/NP the breath.

---

If you have a good understanding of Linear Algebra and have done a decent amount of Circuit work, than it wouldn't be terrible. If you are new to Linear Algebra or have never done circuits, that schedule might get painful.

I personally think that's a pretty heavy workload, and it'd require very good time management, but also doable. Others can feel free to chime in.

children.subject: What about 2? Maybe just EE16A and CS70?
I would say that is doable. Both have pretty constant problem sets, so week- to -week workload would be fairly predictable!
Taking 170, 61C, 188 right now. Three CS classes is doable, but I'd recommend against it if possible. If you have to take it be ready for a challenging semester.

history.content:
I'm a sophomore who has taken CS61A and 61B, and I'm looking to declare CS asap to get into upper div classes by the start of Junior year. I'm thinking of just taking those three classes listed above. Is the above schedule too much in terms of workload?  

Also, will I have an ample amount of time to take enough upper div classes in just two years? I'm hoping to take 170, 169, 186, EE16B, 160, and 174 by the time I graduate. How am I pacing my CS course track, given that I've only taken 2 CS courses over 3 semesters.
history.subject: Too much: CS70 + EE16A + CS61C?
